oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Opothele-Yoholo
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek leader Opothele-Yoholo (Opothleyahola) in printed tunic with beaded sash and feathered headwear.

Opothele-Yoholo was born at Tuckabatchee, Creek Nation (later Alabama), the son of a white father and a Native American mother. He was an important figure in Creek political affairs during the winter of 1824-1825, opposing the sale of Creek land to the government of Georgia. He resisted removal, but in 1836 was obligated to lead 15,000 of his people to the Indian Territory in the west. Opothele-Yoholo was also involved in Civil War battles against the Confederate forces.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas L. (Thomas Loraine), 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
